headline: Delta Variant Forces Japan to Extend State of Emergency
abstract: Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan announced that the government would expand a state of emergency to other areas besides Tokyo, and that the restrictions in the capital would be extended until the end of August after the Olympics concludes.

headline: Ryan Murphy casts doubt on whether a Russian swimmer beat him cleanly.
abstract: The American lost the men’s 200-meter backstroke and then, at a news conference, mentioned Russia’s problems with doping.

headline: Justice Dept. sues Texas governor over an executive order on migrants.
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott’s order bars private transportation suppliers from providing ground transit to many migrants, and the federal government says it is unconstitutional.

headline: Roberto Calasso, Renaissance Man of Letters, Dies at 80
abstract: A Florentine by birth, he was a polymath as an author and publisher (Kafka, Vedic philosophy, Greek mythology) who reached a wide international readership.

headline: My Country Has Been a Dictatorship Before. We Can’t Go Back.
abstract: One-man rule is not the solution to Tunisia's economic problems.

headline: Some New Yorkers say $100 offer inspired them to get vaccinated.
abstract: New Yorkers lined up in the Bronx and Brooklyn to get vaccinated on the first day of cash was offered to get vaccinated at city-run sites.

headline: Richard Lamm, Governor and Early Abortion Rights Supporter, Dies at 85
abstract: He spearheaded the passage of a liberal abortion law in Colorado before Roe v. Wade, and he helped stop the 1976 Winter Olympics from being held in the state.

headline: ‘This Isn’t How We’re Supposed to Live’: Residents Flee as Dixie Fire Surges
abstract: Thousands have had to leave their homes in what has grown into a grim ritual in wildfire-plagued Northern California. Many are demanding answers from PG&E, the large utility company.

headline: A Nigerian sprinter is suspended after a failed drug test.
abstract: Ten other athletes from Nigeria were told they did not meet out-of-competition testing requirements leading up to the Olympics.

headline: ‘It Feels Like We’re Just Waiting to Die’: Hong Kong Targets Student Unions
abstract: The authorities are clamping down on universities, which they consider hotbeds for unrest. The groups say they are fighting for survival.

headline: For Katie Ledecky, the Longer the Race the Better
abstract: How Katie Ledecky’s competitors are closing the gap on her dominance in the pool.

headline: Body of Reuters Photographer Was Mutilated in Taliban Custody, Officials Say
abstract: The body of Danish Siddiqui, a Pulitzer Prize winner killed in Afghanistan, was unrecognizable when it was brought to a Kandahar hospital, one official said.

headline: Accusations of Sexual Abuse Continue to Roil Basketball in Mali
abstract: One Malian basketball leader has been suspended and another jailed in a scandal that has cast a shadow on the president of the sport’s worldwide governing body.

headline: A Plant That ‘Cannot Die’ Reveals Its Genetic Secrets
abstract: Events in the genome of Welwitschia have given it the ability to survive in an unforgiving desert for thousands of years.

headline: Good Fences Make Good Neighbors? Not at Opus 40.
abstract: The scenic vistas of this landscape art and the legacy of its creator, Harvey Fite, are being challenged by a persistent feud and a big fence.

headline: In South Africa, Poachers Now Traffic in Tiny Succulent Plants
abstract: Police search the desert trying to track down the poachers selling Conophytums to collectors worldwide, threatening to wipe out rare plants in the wild.

headline: As Fears Grip Afghanistan, Hundreds of Thousands Flee
abstract: With the Taliban sweeping across much of the country, at least 30,000 Afghans are leaving each week. Many more have been displaced within Afghanistan’s borders.

headline: For Tenants Nationwide, a Scramble to Pay Months of Rent or Face Eviction
abstract: A federal eviction moratorium is scheduled to end on Saturday. Many tenants are packing up and facing an uncertain future.

headline: India’s married archers: ‘We are a powerful couple.’
abstract: Known as Dee-Das in India, Deepika Kumari and Atanu Das are one of two pairs of married archers at the Tokyo Olympics.

headline: After 670 Days, the Blue Jays Finally Returned to Canada
abstract: With a pandemic-forced sojourn to Buffalo and Florida now complete, Toronto’s exciting young team got a chance to experience its actual home crowd.

headline: Mourning Families Seek Solace From the ‘Grief Purgatory’ of Covid-19
abstract: The pandemic has left hundreds of thousands of Americans alone in bereavement, unable to plan proper funerals for their loved ones. Now, they’re planning larger celebrations of life.

headline: The Long Kiss Goodbye: Will Covid End the French Bise Forever?
abstract: Social distancing made the cheek kiss a much rarer greeting, and polling suggests it may stay that way. Some say good riddance, but others miss the warmth of times past.

headline: Key Afghan City in Danger of Falling to the Taliban
abstract: Government reinforcements arrived Saturday in Lashkar Gar, the capital of Helmand Province, but people were fleeing their homes and a hospital in the city had been bombed.

headline: Stranded Killer Whale Survives With Help of Good Samaritans
abstract: Rescuers and wildlife officials kept it cool and wet while waiting for a rising tide. The orca returned to sea about six hours after it was spotted on the rugged shores of an Alaskan island.

headline: A Smarter Way to Make Decisions About Your Kids
abstract: What parents can learn from the strategies of well-run companies.

headline: U.S. fencers wear pink masks to protest against teammate accused of sexual misconduct.
abstract: Alen Hadzic, an alternate on the men’s fencing team, was left wearing a black mask while three of his teammates wore pink ones during competition on Friday.

headline: How Fast the Jamaican Sprinters Ran to Sweep the Women’s 100 Meters
abstract: The gold medalist, Elaine Thompson-Herah, averaged more than 21 miles per hour to finish the race in 10.61 seconds.

headline: Biden Promised to Restore the Iran Nuclear Deal. Now It Risks Derailment.
abstract: Both sides have much to lose if a delicate negotiation over limiting Iran’s activities in return for a lifting of sanctions falls short.

headline: Olympics’ First Openly Transgender Woman Stokes Debate on Fairness
abstract: Laurel Hubbard, a 43-year-old weight lifter from New Zealand, will compete on Monday, as some question her right to be at the Games.

headline: Who Are the Unvaccinated in America? There’s No One Answer.
abstract: One segment of people who have avoided shots is vehemently opposed to the idea. But there is a second group, surveys suggest, that is still deciding.

headline: Police in China Detain Canadian Pop Star on Suspicion of Rape
abstract: Kris Wu, a 30-year-old celebrity, is the most prominent figure in China to be held over #MeToo allegations.

headline: San Marino becomes the smallest country to win an Olympic medal.
abstract: San Marino waited 61 years for its first Olympic medal. With a population of roughly 30,000, it is the smallest country to win an Olympic medal, surpassing Bermuda

headline: ‘It’s Nowhere Near Over’: A Beach Town’s Gust of Freedom, Then a U-turn
abstract: Provincetown, Mass., the quirky community at the tip of Cape Cod, thought it was safe to return to prepandemic partying. It wasn’t.

headline: Delta Variant Drives Global Virus Surge, W.H.O. Warns
abstract: Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the World Health Organization’s director general, said a worldwide rise in Covid-19 cases has disparately impacted poorer countries with lower vaccination rates, and that deaths in Africa have spiked 80 percent in four weeks.

headline: 233 staff members at 2 San Francisco hospitals have tested positive, most in breakthrough Delta infections.
abstract: Vaccinations warded off severe Covid for most of the workers, who tested positive this month; two required hospitalization.

headline: Protests against France’s vaccine pass surge for a third weekend, even as cases rise.
abstract: The government’s health pass law was passed by Parliament and is expected to get a final greenlight from a top constitutional council next week.
